title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly identify the intermolecular forces in both compounds.

· Compound Q – dispersion forces

· Compound Z – dispersion forces and dipole-dipole forces

The response correctly identifies the intermolecular forces in both compounds.

· Compound Q – dispersion forces

· Compound Z – dispersion forces and dipole-dipole forces

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide a correct explanation equivalent to the following.

· The greater number of atoms in compound Z leads to a larger, more polarizable electron cloud than in compound Q, and correspondingly stronger London dispersion forces. Compound Z also has relatively strong dipole-dipole forces. The total intermolecular forces are therefore stronger in compound Z than in compound Q, resulting in a higher boiling point.

The response provides a correct explanation equivalent to the following.

· The greater number of atoms in compound Z leads to a larger, more polarizable electron cloud than in compound Q, and correspondingly stronger London dispersion forces. Compound Z also has relatively strong dipole-dipole forces. The total intermolecular forces are therefore stronger in compound Z than in compound Q, resulting in a higher boiling point.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide both the correct answer and a valid justification equivalent to the following.

· Yes. The second peak in the diagram having the largest activation energy is consistent with the second elementary step being rate-determining. The lower energy of the products relative to the reactants is consistent with an exothermic reaction.

The response provides correct answer and a valid justification equivalent to the following.

· Yes. The second peak in the diagram having the largest activation energy is consistent with the second elementary step being rate-determining. The lower energy of the products relative to the reactants is consistent with an exothermic reaction.
